Yeats]] (1871–1957) ** ''Bachelor's Walk, in Memory'' 1915 (On loan from a private collection)http://www.nationalgallery.ie/en/aboutus/pressroom/2009PressReleases/Recovered_Yeats_painting.aspx ** ''The Liffey Swim'' 1923 ** ''A Morning in a City'' 1937 ** ''Grief'' 1952 * [[John Butler Yeats]] (1839–1922) ''John O'Leary'' 1904 === Drawings and watercolours === *[[James Malton]] (1760–1803) ''The Custom House'' *[[Joseph Mallord William Turner]] (1775–1851) ''Fishing Boats on Folkestone Beach'' *[[Dante Gabriel Rossetti]] (1828–82) ''Jane Burden as Queen Guinevere'' 1858 *[[Frederick William Burton]] (1816–1900) ''Hellelil and Hildebrand, the Meeting on Turret Stairs, 1864'' 1864 *[[James Abbott McNeill Whistler]] (1834–1903) ''Nocturne in Grey and Gold – Piccadilly, 1881–83'' *[[Edgar Degas]] (1834–1917) ''Two Ballet Dancers in a Dressing Room'' *[[Pablo Ruiz Picasso]] (1881–1973) ''Two Dancers'' 1925 == Library & Archive Collections == The [https://www.nationalgallery.ie/what-we-do/library-and-archives library and archive collections] at the National Gallery of Ireland encompass unique and historically significant collections for the study of art history. The origins of the collections can be traced back to the foundation of the institution over one hundred and sixty years ago. Covering the visual arts from the classical to the contemporary these collections continue to be a vital research element of the National Collection. The development of the library and archive has been supported principally through public funding and the private donations of generous benefactors. Open to the public, it has particularly rich holdings relating to the history of western European art from the middle ages on, and the collections relating to Irish and Italian art are extensive. The collection amounts to over 100,000 published volumes, in addition to significant archival holdings. == References == ===Sources=== ;[[Irish Statute Book]] * [http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/1854/act/99/enacted/en/html National Gallery of Ireland Act 1854] * [http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/1855/act/44/enacted/en/html National Gallery of Ireland Act 1855] * National Gallery (Amendment) Act 1865: see {{cite book|title=Public General Statutes |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=5EMvAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA307 |volume=28 & 29 Vict. |year=1865 |publisher=Eyre and Spottiswoode |pages=307–310 |chapter=Cap. LXXI: An Act to amend the Acts for the Establishment of a National Gallery in Dublin |location=London}} * [http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/1928/act/20/enacted/en/html National Gallery of Ireland Act 1928] * [http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/1963/act/5/enacted/en/html National Gallery of Ireland Act 1963] * [http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/1997/act/11/enacted/en/print#partvi National Cultural Institutions Act 1997, Part VI] ;Secondary: * Raymond Keaveney (2002), ''The National Gallery of Ireland: Essential Guide''. London: Scala Publishers. {{ISBN|1-85759-267-0}} * Homan Potterton (2003), ''The National Gallery of Ireland'' in Brian Lalor (Ed.) ''[[The Encyclopedia of Ireland]]''. Dublin: Gill & Macmillan. {{ISBN|0-7171-3000-2}} * Homan Potterton, Introduction to ''National Gallery of Ireland: Illustrated Summary Catalogue of Paintings''. Dublin: Gill & Macmillan. {{ISBN|0-7171-1145-8}} ===Citations=== {{Reflist}} {{commons category|National Gallery of Ireland}} == External links == *[http://www.nationalgallery.ie/ National Gallery of Ireland website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20030303020758/http://www.irish-architecture.com/buildings_ireland/dublin/southcity/clare_street/ngi.html The Millennium Wing on Irish-architecture.com] *[http://www.dippam.ac.uk/eppi/eppi_lc_subjects/2838 Reports of the Director of the National Gallery of Ireland 1883–1920] from EPPI (Enhanced British Parliamentary Papers on Ireland) {{Museums and Galleries in Ireland}} {{National Cultural Institutions of Ireland}} {{RTÉ Performing Groups}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Art museums established in 1864]] [[Category:Art museums and galleries in the Republic of Ireland]] [[Category:Arts in Dublin (city)]] [[Category:Irish art]] [[Category:National museums of the Republic of Ireland]] [[Category:Museums in Dublin (city)]] [[Category:1864 establishments in Ireland]] [[Category:National galleries|Ireland]]

revision.comment: /* Postmodern Communication Models */[[WP:AWB/T|Typo fixing]], replaced: According → According to using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
'''Postmodern Communication''' is used to describe the communication and messaging format, styles, guides, technologies and media used in a postmodernist world. Due to its non-traditional means; postmodern communication is also referred to as the information society.{{Cite book|title=From the Modern to the Postmodern: The future of global communications theory and research in a pandemonic age|last=Braman |first=Sandra |year=2003 |publisher=Sage Publications, Thousand Hills, CA, |pages=109–123 }} Driven by the need to reach influential audiences and to cut through a cluttered promotional marketplace, brands are reaching out to new communication methods to deliver their advertising message. Furthermore, many marketing practitioners are cited as saying that in order to create successful marketing strategies in the twenty-first century, "more creative thinking allied to an integrated approach to all communication activities are needed".{{Cite book|title="Communication in postmodern integrated marketing",|last= Proctor |first= Tony |year=2002 |publisher=Corporate Communications: An International Journal, Vol. 7 Iss: 3|pages=144–154 }} == Origins == The origin of postmodern communication is linked to the development of communication theory. As communication theory studies the technical process of information and the process of human communication, postmodern communications are the newly created tools and marketplaces that allow these communications to happen.{{Cite book|title="Communication In Postmodern Integrated Marketing",|last1= Dainton |first1= Marianne |last2= Zellei |first2= Elain | year=2011 |publisher=Sage Publications.|page= 247 |isbn= 1-4129-7691-X }} Most thinking around the postmodern communication and marketing model is driven from an early 90's scholastic journal article created by Stephen Brown and posted to the England Journal of Marketing.{{Cite book|title=Postmodern Marketing?|last=Brown |first=Steven |year=1993 |publisher=European Journal of Marketing, Vol. 27 Iss: 4|pages=19–34 |issn=0309-0566 }} In it Brown writes, one who approaches marketing from postmodern style should in many ways reject attempts to impost order and working in silos. Instead markers should work collectively from with artistic attributes of intuition, creativity, spontaneity, speculation, emotion and involvement. == Postmodern Communication Models == With the raise of the internet in the early 1960s and the explosive growth of social networking and mobile phones in the 1980 era, many more tactical postmodern communication models have from. Below is a short list on these new emerging messaging/communication models. {| border="1" cellpadding="1" ! scope="col" width="125" | Model ! scope="col" width="200" | Medium ! scope="col" width="200" | Example |- |
Real Time|| Social || Hashtags, Twitter, Facebook |- | || IM || gChat, AOL IM |- | || Video Call || Skype, FaceTime, |- | || Location-Based Notification || Geofencing |- |
Delayed Response|| Email || |- | ||Telemarketing || |- |
Undirectional || TV || :30 sec ads |- | || Radio || Weather Alerts |- | || Print || Magazines |}
In adherence with postmodern communications one can assume that the current trend around marketing communication is within the real time model. Although this may be the case it is important to realize that these communication models do not accurately depict how brands and advertisers are spending in the space. According to leading advertising spending and research provider, spending around new aged "response" media is set at around 20% of total media spend, while unidirectional models make up roughly 80%.{{Cite web|url=http://www.emarketer.com/PressRelease.aspx?R=1008432 |title= Online Advertising Market Poised to Grow 20% in 2011 |publisher=emarketer.com |date=2011-06-08 |accessdate=2011-12-21}} == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Advertising]] [[Category:Promotion and marketing communications]] [[Category:Communication design]] [[Category:Brand management]] [[Category:Postmodernism]]

revision.comment: Undid revision 836835141 by [[Special:Contributions/Wikievil666|Wikievil666]] ([[User talk:Wikievil666|talk]]) — [[WP:OR]]? This is not in cited reference.
revision.text:
{{Infobox Painting <!-- image is deliberately not included in the infobox, as it is better presented using the {{Wide image}} template --> | title = Prosperous Suzhou | artist = [[Xu Yang (Qing dynasty)|Xu Yang]] | year = 1759<ref name="VAM-detail">{{cite web |title=Prosperous Suzhou (detail) |url=http://www.vam.ac.uk/users/node/19038 |publisher=[[Victoria and Albert Museum]] |accessdate=November 13, 2013}}</ref> | type = [[Handscroll|Handscroll; ink and color on silk.]] | height_metric = 35.8 | width_metric = 1225 | height_imperial = 14 | width_imperial = 482 | city=[[Shenyang]]<ref name="VAM-detail" /> | museum=[[Liaoning Provincial Museum]] }}
'''''Prosperous Suzhou''''' ({{zh|t={{linktext|姑蘇|繁華|圖}}|s={{linktext|姑苏|繁华|图}}|p=Gūsū Fánhuá Tú}}), originally entitled '''''Burgeoning Life in a Resplendent Age''''' ({{zh|t={{linktext|盛世|滋生|圖}}|s={{linktext|盛世|滋生|图}}|p=Shèngshì Zīshēng Tú}}), is an 18th-century scroll painting ([[handscroll]]) created in 1759 by the Chinese court painter [[Xu Yang (Qing dynasty)|Xu Yang]]. Depicting the bustling urban life of [[Suzhou]], it combines Western perspective with traditional Chinese style.
== History == The [[Qianlong Emperor]] commissioned ''Prosperous Suzhou'' after he returned from an inspection trip to the south in 1751.<ref name="hk">{{cite web |title=Paintings depict prosperous cities of Ming and Qing dynasties |url=http://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/200909/24/P200909240131.htm |publisher=info.gov.hk |date=September 24, 2009 |accessdate=November 13, 2013}}</ref> It took several years for Xu Yang, a native of Suzhou, to complete.<ref name="hk" /> ''Prosperous Suzhou'' was renamed from ''Burgeoning Life in a Resplendent Age'' in the 1950s.<ref name="Drawing-Boundaries">{{cite book |last=Chung |first=Anita |year=2004 |title=Drawing Boundaries: Architectural Images in Qing China |publisher=University of Hawaii Press |isbn=9780824826635}}</ref>
== Description ==
{{Wide image|Prosperous Suzhou.jpg|10000px|''Prosperous Suzhou'' by Xu Yang|dir=rtl}}
''Prosperous Suzhou'' is a [[handscroll]], a long narrow scroll for displaying a series of scenes. It is twelve meters in length.<ref name="hk" /> It is intended to be viewed starting from the right end, by laying it flat on a table and unrolling it. One admires it section for section during the unrolling as if traveling through a landscape, depicting a continuous journey.<ref name="Delbanco">Delbanco, Dawn (2008). [http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/chhs/hd_chhs.htm "Chinese Handscrolls"]. In ''Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History''. New York: The Metropolitan Museum of Art. Retrieved November 13, 2013.</ref>
European art and its techniques like [[linear perspective]] became increasingly influential in China the 18th and 19th centuries.<ref name="VAM-1600-1900">{{cite web |title=Masterpieces of Chinese Painting 700 - 1900: Challenging the Past and Looking to the West 1600-1900 |url=http://www.vam.ac.uk/users/album/18977 |publisher=[[Victoria and Albert Museum]] |accessdate=November 13, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131113230902/http://www.vam.ac.uk/users/album/18977 |archivedate=November 13, 2013 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> Skillfully composed, ''Prosperous Suzhou'' combines Western linear perspective with traditional Chinese compositional devices.<ref name="Drawing-Boundaries" /><ref name="VAM-1600-1900" /> The scroll is invaluable from both a historical and an artistic point of view,<ref name="JoA">{{Cite journal | last1 = Hung | first1 = W. C. P. | title = The city so prosperous: Episodes of urban life in Suzhou | doi = 10.1080/136023600419591 | journal = The Journal of Architecture | volume = 5 | issue = 3 | pages = 267–291 | year = 2000 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref> depicting in intricate detail the mid-18th century topography and customs of [[Suzhou]], allowing modern viewers to visit a Chinese city of 250 years ago.<ref name="hk" />
In his inscription at the end of the scroll, Xu Yang wrote that he painted it in order to depict a peaceful and prosperous reign, and to pay homage to the reign of the [[Qianlong Emperor]].<ref name="Harvard">{{cite web |title=Suzhou Scroll |url=http://sites.fas.harvard.edu/~hsa13/scroll/suzhou_viewer.html |publisher=[[Harvard]] |accessdate=November 13, 2013}}</ref> In addition, his inscription describes the scroll as a journey from [[Mount Lingyan]] to the city walls of Suzhou, through the city, and ending at [[Tiger Hill, Suzhou|Tiger Hill]].<ref name="Drawing-Boundaries" />
The scroll vividly illustrates the visual appearance of the terrain, urban landscapes, and everyday life in an area covering several dozen miles. The middle of the scroll depicts an idealised view of all the activities of the bustling urban center of Suzhou. Viewers can see numerous merchants, traders, barges and passenger boats, as well as dense rows of shops and vendors. More than 4,800 human figures,<ref name="hk" /> 2,000 architectural structures,<ref name="hk" /> and 400 boats<ref name="Harvard" /> are present.
<gallery widths="200px"> File:Xu_Yang_-_Women_of_the_village_working.jpg|Village women at work File:Xu_Yang_-_Theatre_play.jpg|Theater File:Xu_Yang_-_Commerce_on_the_water.jpg|Commerce on the water File:Xu_Yang_-_Examination_hall.jpg|Examination hall File:Xu_Yang_-_Marriage.jpg|Marriage ceremony File:Xu_Yang_-_Tiger_Hill_in_Suzhou.jpg|Tiger Hill and artist's inscription </gallery>
== Exhibitions ==
''Prosperous Suzhou'' along with fourteen other paintings (all on the subject of the prosperous cities of the [[Ming dynasty]] and [[Qing dynasty]]) from the [[Liaoning Provincial Museum]] were exhibited at the [[Hong Kong Museum of Art]] from 25 September 2009 to 22 November 2009 to celebrate the 60th anniversary of the founding of the [[China|People's Republic of China]].<ref name="hk" />
The [[Victoria and Albert Museum]] in [[London]] mounted an exhibition entitled ''Masterpieces of Chinese Painting'' that included ''Prosperous Suzhou'' from 26 October 2013 to 19 January 2014. The exhibition was organized to display the finest examples of Chinese painting from the beginning of the 8th to the end of the 19th century.<ref name="VAM-exhibition" />
In 2016, a booklet was published entitled "Prosperous Suzhou" which displays a painted copy of Xu Yang's original. The booklet includes an explanation in English of what is seen in each half-metre. [http://www.blurb.com/b/6958888-prosperous-suzhou]
== See also == * [[Chinese painting]] * ''[[Along the River During the Qingming Festival]]''
== References == {{Reflist|30em|refs= <ref name="VAM-exhibition">{{cite web |title=Masterpieces of Chinese Painting 700 - 1900: About the Exhibition |url=http://www.vam.ac.uk/content/exhibitions/masterpieces-of-chinese-painting/about-the-exhibition/ |publisher=[[Victoria and Albert Museum]] |accessdate=November 13, 2013}}</ref> }}
== External links == {{Commons category|Prosperous Suzhou}} * [http://sites.fas.harvard.edu/~hsa13/scroll/suzhou_viewer.html Suzhou Scroll], zoomable panoramic viewer depicting details of ''Prosperous Suzhou''. * {{YouTube|id=VCsAVcTZ2xY|title=''Prosperous Suzhou''}}<!-- see talk page note for permission info-->, an [[RTHK]] segment about the 2009 exhibition of ''Prosperous Suzhou'' in Hong Kong.
[[Category:Chinese paintings]] [[Category:1759 paintings]] [[Category:Culture in Suzhou]] [[Category:Maritime paintings]]

page.title: Reviewing Committee on the Export of Works of Art

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Department for Culture, Media and Sport]]; added [[Category:Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
The '''Reviewing Committee on the Export of Works of Art and Objects of Cultural Interest''' (RCEWA) is a [[committee]] of the [[United Kingdom]] government, advising the [[Department of Culture, Media and Sport]] (DCMS) on the export of [[cultural property]]. Some of its roles were shifted to the [[Museums, Libraries and Archives Council]] (MLA) in 2005 after the Goodison Report and the Arts Council England now provides the secretariat to the Committee. It is currently chaired by Sir [[Hayden Phillips]], who was appointed on 17 March 2014 for a term of five years.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.artscouncil.org.uk/sites/default/files/download-file/RCEWA%20members%20May%202017.pdf |title=Membership of the Reviewing Committee on the Export of Works of Art and Objects of Cultural Interest |website=Arts Council England |date=May 2017 |accessdate=8 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://www.artscouncil.org.uk/sites/default/files/download-file/Export%20Objects%20Cultural%20Interest%202015-16.pdf |author=Reviewing Committee on the Export of Works of Art and Objects of Cultural Interest |title=62nd Annual Report (May 2015–April 2016) |publisher=Department for Culture Media & Sport |date=23 February 2017 |isbn=978-1-4741-3874-1 |accessdate=8 October 2017}}</ref>
If an artwork is sold to a foreign buyer, it also advises the DCMS on whether to delay the granting of an export licence in order to allow time for a British buyer to raise funds to buy the work instead and keep it in the UK, if the committee decides the work is of high enough quality and has a sufficiently significant British connection - this is known as an export bar.
==Waverley Criteria== The RCEWA was established in 1952, in accordance with the recommendations of the [[Viscount Waverley|Waverley]] Committee, and assesses the objects before it against the three "Waverley Criteria":<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.artscouncil.org.uk/export-controls/reviewing-committee#section-2 |title=Reviewing Committee: How decisions are made |website=[[Arts Council England]] |accessdate=8 October 2017}}</ref> * Is it so closely connected with our history and national life that its departure would be a misfortune? * Is it of outstanding aesthetic importance? * Is it of outstanding significance for the study of some particular branch of art, learning or history?
==Chair== * [[Lionel Robbins]] : 1952–1954.<ref>{{cite Hansard |house=House of Commons |title=Export of Works of Art (Government Decision) |url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/written_answers/1952/dec/09/export-of-works-of-art-government#S5CV0509P0_19521209_CWA_125 |date=9 December 1952 | column=38W |speaker=[[Rab Butler|R. A. B. Butler]] |position=[[Chancellor of the Exchequer]]}}</ref> * [[John Fremantle, 4th Baron Cottesloe|Lord Cottesloe]]: 1954–1972.<ref>{{cite Hansard |house=House of Lords |title=Works of Art: Export Control |url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/lords/1973/mar/15/works-of-art-export-control |date=15 March 1973 | column=493 |speaker=[[David Kenworthy, 11th Baron Strabolgi|Lord Strabolgi]]}}</ref> * [[David Drummond, 8th Earl of Perth|Lord Perth]] : 1972–1976.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/the-earl-of-perth-138424.html |title=The Earl of Perth |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |date=30 November 2002 |accessdate=8 October 2017}}</ref> * [[John White (art historian)|John White]] : 1976–1982.<ref>{{cite Hansard |house=House of Commons |title=Works of Art (Export) |url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/commons/1976/oct/28/works-of-art-export#S5CV0918P0_19761028_HOC_510 |date=28 October 1976 |column=842 |speaker=[[Hugh Jenkins, Baron Jenkins of Putney|Hugh Jenkins]] |position=MP for [[Putney (UK Parliament constituency)|Putney]]}}</ref> * [[Earl of Plymouth|Lord Plymouth]] : 1982–1985.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cracroftspeerage.co.uk/online/content/plymouth1905.htm |title=Plymouth, Earl of (UK, 1905) |website=Cracroft's Peerage |accessdate=8 October 2017}}</ref> * Jonathan Scott : 1985–1995.<ref>{{cite journal |url=https://www.questia.com/library/journal/1P3-3046620501/jonathan-scott-1940-2012-cbe-fsa |first=Mark |last=Fisher |title=Jonathan Scott CBE, FSA (1940–2012) |journal=The Sculpture Journal |volume=22 |issue=1 |date=1 June 2013 |accessdate=8 October 2017 |via=[[Questia]]}}</ref> * Sir [[John Guinness]] : 1995–2003.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.culture.gov.uk/NR/rdonlyres/ez7ie2glx4uvpplyin6zuefhhiglj7mcwomimarxwexqooe4t5kgkw6wsghtsrxypkwhnw6bb2sae7zq6rreka43wea/culturalpropertyguidanceforexporters.pdf |title=UK Export Licensing For Cultural Goods |website=Department for Culture, Media and Sport |date=28 February 2003 |archiveurl=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20031220232550/http://www.culture.gov.uk/NR/rdonlyres/ez7ie2glx4uvpplyin6zuefhhiglj7mcwomimarxwexqooe4t5kgkw6wsghtsrxypkwhnw6bb2sae7zq6rreka43wea/culturalpropertyguidanceforexporters.pdf |archivedate=20 December 2003 |accessdate=8 October 2017}}</ref> * [[Richard Fletcher-Vane, 2nd Baron Inglewood|Lord Inglewood]] : 2003–2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.culture.gov.uk/images/publications/ACE_Export_of_Objects_of_Cultural_Interest.pdf |title=Export of Objects of Cultural Interest 2011/12 |website=Department for Culture, Media and Sport |date=December 2012 |accessdate=8 October 2017}}</ref> * Sir [[Hayden Phillips]] : 2014–2019.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/new-appointment-to-the-reviewing-committee-on-the-export-of-works-of-art-and-objects-of-cultural-interest |title=New appointment to the Reviewing Committee on the Export of Works of Art and Objects of Cultural Interest |website=Department for Digital, Culture, Media & Sport |date=6 March 2014 |accessdate=8 October 2017}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Values (heritage)]] * [[Modern Rome – Campo Vaccino]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.artscouncil.org.uk/export-controls/reviewing-committee}} * {{cite web |url=http://www.39essex.com/docs/articles/RH_Reviewing_Committee_Christies_0105.pdf |first=Richard |last=Harwood |title=The Work of the Reviewing Committee on the Export of Works of Art |website=[[39 Essex Chambers]] |date=2004}}

revision.comment: /* History */replaced: Director → director, Prime Minister → prime minister, President → president (2), Academy → academy (2), Council → council
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use British English|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox Museum |name = Royal West of England Academy |image = Royal West of England Academy.jpg |caption = |established =1844 |location =[[Clifton, Bristol]], [[England]] |map_type =Bristol |coordinates = {{coord|51.45810|-2.60840|display=inline,title}} |visitors = |director = Alison Bevan |website =[http://www.rwa.org.uk/ Royal West of England Academy]
}} The '''Royal West of England Academy''' ('''RWA''') is Bristol's oldest art gallery, located in [[Clifton, Bristol|Clifton]], [[Bristol]], near the junction of Queens Road and [[Whiteladies Road]]. Situated in a Grade 2* listed building, it hosts five galleries and an exhibition programme that celebrates the best of historic and contemporary British art.
== History ==
The Royal West of England Academy was the first art gallery to be established in Bristol. Its foundation was financed by a bequest of £2,000 in the will of [[Ellen Sharples]] in 1849,<ref>{{cite web|title=Royal West Of England Academy|url=http://www.saatchigallery.com/museums/museum-profile/Royal+West+Of+England+Academy/378.html|publisher=Saatchi Gallery|accessdate=20 December 2015}}</ref> and a well-known group of artists in Bristol, known as the Bristol Society of Artists.<ref>{{cite web|title=History|url=http://www.rwa.org.uk/about/history/|publisher=Royal West of England Academy|accessdate=20 December 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222121310/http://www.rwa.org.uk/about/history/|archivedate=22 December 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name=artbiogs>{{cite web|title=Royal West of England Academy|url=http://www.artbiogs.co.uk/2/societies/royal-west-england-academy|publisher=Artist Biographies|accessdate=20 December 2015}}</ref> These were mostly landscape painters, and many, such as [[William James Müller]], [[Francis Danby]], [[James Baker Pyne]] and [[John Syer]] were well known.<ref name=artbiogs/> In 1844, when the Bristol Academy for the Promotion of Fine Arts was founded, the Bristol Society of Artists was incorporated into it. At this time the president and committee was predominantly its patrons, rather than its artists. In 1913 King [[George V of the United Kingdom|George V]] granted the academy its Royal title,<ref>{{cite web|title=Mapping the Practice and Profession of Sculpture in Britain and Ireland 1851-1951|url=http://sculpture.gla.ac.uk/view/organization.php?id=msib1_1218014208|publisher=University of Glasgow|accessdate=20 December 2015}}</ref> with the reigning monarch as its Patron,<ref name=bridgeman>{{cite web|title=Royal West of England Academy|url=http://www.bridgemanimages.com/en-GB/collections/collection/royal-west-of-england-academy/|publisher=Bridgeman Images|accessdate=19 August 2018}}</ref> and by 1914 a major extension to the front of the building, including the dome and [[Walter Crane]] lunettes, was completed.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Lunettes|url=http://www.elizabethholford.co.uk/thelunettes.html|publisher=Elizabeth Holford Associates|accessdate=20 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Willsdon|first1=Clare A.|title=Mural Painting in Britain 1840-1940: Image and Meaning|date=2000|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780198175155|page=283|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=oNJo8VKfBmkC&pg=PA283&lpg=PA283&dq=Royal+West+of+England+Academy+Walter+Crane+lunettes+1914&source=bl&ots=e60D39G8sn&sig=7KcY1eJLHJxYwMNtMD8v_O5Bk5Q&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjczZHJhevJAhUHuhoKHRqxDi0Q6AEIOzAF#v=onepage&q=Royal%20West%20of%20England%20Academy%20Walter%20Crane%20lunettes%201914&f=false}}</ref>
During [[World War II]] the academy building was taken over by various organisations including the [[Bristol Aeroplane Company]] and the [[U.S. Army]].<ref name=bridgeman/> Immediately after the war ended the council applied for the release of the galleries but was informed that they would be occupied by the [[Inland Revenue]] until further notice. It was not until 1950 that the building was returned to its original function, after the intervention of the then prime minister, [[Clement Attlee]].<ref>{{cite web|title=History of the RWA |work=Royal West of England Academy |url=http://www.rwa.org.uk/histfrm.htm |accessdate=2006-08-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716064532/http://www.rwa.org.uk/histfrm.htm |archivedate=16 July 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref name=bridgeman/> During the 1950s the Royal West of England Academy Schools became the West of England College of Art.<ref name=artbiogs/> This moved to the Bower Ashton campus in 1966, where it was then absorbed by the University of the West of England (School of Visual Studies), now the [[Department of Creative Industries, UWE, Bristol]]. The current president is the artist Stewart Geddes PRWA and director is Alison Bevan BEM.
== Collections ==
Among the paintings in the permanent collection are works by artists from the [[Newlyn School|Newlyn]], [[St Ives, Cornwall|St Ives]] and [[Bloomsbury]] Schools and paintings by [[Elizabeth Blackadder]], [[Bernard Dunstan]], [[Mary Fedden]], [[Matthew Hale (artist)|Matthew Hale]], [[David Inshaw]], [[Derek Balmer]], [[Anne Redpath]], [[George Swaish]] and [[Carel Weight]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Permanent Collection|url=http://www.rwa.org.uk/rwa-artists/permanent-collection/|publisher=Royal West of England Academy|accessdate=20 December 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120110143924/http://www.rwa.org.uk/rwa-artists/permanent-collection/|archivedate=10 January 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
== Building == [[File:Gallery Space.jpg|upright|thumb|RWA Galleries]] [[File:Gallery Friezes.jpg|thumb|Marble Gallery Friezes]] [[File:RWA Lunettes.jpg|upright|thumb|Walter Crane Lunettes]]
The building is a grade II* [[listed building]] constructed in 1857 as the city's first public art gallery, also encompassing an art school. It opened in 1858. The interiors are by [[Charles Underwood]] and facade by [[JR Hirst]], altered in 1912 by [[SS Reay]] and [[H Dare Bryan]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Royal West of England Academy|url=http://www.historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1282156|website=National Heritage List for England|publisher=Historic England|accessdate=20 December 2015}}</ref> The first floor is in 3 sections, the outer ones articulated by paired Corinthian pilasters flanking large shell head niches with statues of [[John Flaxman|Flaxman]] and [[Joshua Reynolds|Reynolds]]. A large carving of 3 female figures - the three graces - crowns the parapet. The interior includes coloured [[marble]] and a replica of the [[Parthenon Frieze]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Royal West of England Academy |work=Images of England |url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=380286 |accessdate=2006-05-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071208081907/http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=380286 |archivedate= 8 December 2007 |df= }}</ref>
== Presidents == *1844-1859 John Harford *1859-1881 Philip WS Miles *1881-1884 Samuel Lang *1884-1887 Colonel H Savile *1887-1897 Daniel H Cave *1897-1898 Alderman [[Francis Fry]] *1898-1911 Sir [[William Wills, 1st Baron Winterstoke]] *1911-1932 Dame [[Janet Stancomb-Wills]] *1932-1936 Yda Richardson *1936-1971 [[Paul Ayshford Methuen, 4th Baron Methuen|Lord Methuen]] RA *1971-1974 Donald Milner OBE *1974-1984 [[Bernard Dunstan]] RA *1984-1989 [[Mary Fedden]] OBE RA *1989-1995 [[Leonard Manasseh]] OBE RA *1995-2000 Dr Peter Thursby *2000-2010 Dr [[Derek Balmer]] *2010-2011 Simon Quadrat *2011-2016 Dr [[Janette Kerr]] *2016- Stewart Geddes
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == {{Commons category}} * [http://www.rwa.org.uk/ RWA's website]

revision.text:
{{Italic title}} {{Infobox artwork | image_file = Sundial, Boy with Spider.jpg | painting_alignment = Front | image_size = 250px | title = Sundial, Boy With Spider | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = [[Willard Dryden Paddock]] | year = 1916-1918 | type = [[Bronze]] | height_metric = | width_metric = | length_metric = | height_imperial = 30 | width_imperial = 22 | length_imperial = 28 | diameter_metric = | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = in | city = [[Indianapolis, Indiana]], United States | museum = [[Indianapolis Museum of Art]] | coordinates = {{coord|39|49|38.73|N|86|11|2.24|W|region:US-IN|name=Sundial, Boy With Spider by Willard Dryden Paddock (1916)|display=inline,title}} | owner = Indianapolis Museum of Art }}
'''''Sundial, Boy With Spider''''' is an [[outdoor sculpture]] and functional [[sundial]] by American artist [[Willard Dryden Paddock]] (1873–1956). It is located within the [[Oldfields]] estate on the grounds of the [[Indianapolis Museum of Art]] (IMA), in [[Indianapolis]], [[Indiana]], United States. The [[bronze]] sculpture, cast by the [[Gorham Manufacturing Company]], depicts a boy sitting cross-legged with an open scroll in his lap.<ref name="Smithsonian">{{cite web | author=Save Outdoor Sculpture! | year=1993 | title=Sundial, Boy With Spider | work=SIRIS | publisher=Smithsonian | url=http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?&profile=all&source=~!siartinventories&uri=full=3100001~!26004~!0#focus| accessdate= 17 January 2011}}</ref>
==Description== A young boy sits with his ankles crossed and knees spread, holding a sundial in the form of a scroll in his lap; this scroll is marked in a grid of lines with month names and geographic coordinates. In his lap beneath the scroll sits a bundle of flowers. The boy’s proper left hand rests on his left knee. His proper right hand, which is in contact with his head, casually holds a twig over the scroll. A wire wrapped around the end of the twig hangs straight down to the base, where it is affixed. A bronze spider is affixed to the wire in the correct place to act as the [[gnomon]] of the sundial. (The wire, twig, and spider are restorations from 2004.)<ref name=Conservation>Indianapolis Museum of Art. Sundial, Boy With Spider, Acc. # 73.123. 2004 Conservation Condition and Treatment Reports. July 25, 2004. Retrieved from Indianapolis Museum of Art Conservation Archives 19 January 2011.</ref> The boy rests on an oval base.
===Inscribed text===
====Scroll==== Inscribed on the scroll are a grid of lines and [[analemma]]s marked with months, dates, and hours sufficient to plot the time over the course of the year, as well as a set of [[coordinates]] that mark the original location of the sculpture:
:Lat 39°, 50 N 86°, 10 W Long
Inscribed on the proper left bottom corner:
:Dial Marking by Albert C. Crehore, inventor
====Base==== Cast in relief along the edge of the base in Roman letters:
:MARK YE THE HOURS OF LIGHT THAT SLIP AWAY ~ ~ ~ SPIN THEN THY HOUR OF SUNLIGHT WHILE YE MAY ~ ~ ~ ~ ~
Inscribed on the base at proper left:
:© by Willard Paddock Sculptor
:Scpt. | 1916 1917
:PAT. FEB 26 1918-
Stamped along base rim under “WHILE”:
:O. BFC GORHAM CO. FOUNDERS
==Condition== The bronze sculpture is monitored, cleaned, and treated regularly by the IMA art conservation staff. The surface of the bronze is protected from deterioration and corrosion by the yearly application of a fresh coat of hard wax. This sculpture was surveyed in July 1993 of as part of the Smithsonian American Art Museum's Inventories of American Painting and Sculpture database, and it was considered to be well maintained.<ref name="Smithsonian"/> In 2004 the IMA conservation staff undertook a major treatment of the sculpture in which the surface was repatinated to unify the color and improve its readability, and the newly fabricated wire and spider gnomon were added to restore the functionality of the sundial.<ref name=Conservation></ref> In June 2011, the wire and spider are currently missing from the sundial.
==See also== *[[List of Indianapolis Museum of Art artworks]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{IMAart}}
[[Category:1918 establishments in Indiana]] [[Category:1918 sculptures]] [[Category:Bronze sculptures in Indiana]] [[Category:Indianapolis Museum of Art artworks]] [[Category:Outdoor sculptures in Indianapolis]] [[Category:Sculptures of children in the United States]] [[Category:Spiders in art]] [[Category:Statues in Indianapolis]]

{{Refimprove|date=September 2014}} {{Italic title|reason=[[:Category:Korean words and phrases]]}} [[File:Homage rock 1885.jpeg|thumb|right|Korean artwork shows scholar paying homage to a special stone -- painting with calligraphy by Hô Ryôn, 1885]]
'''''Suseok''''' (수석), also called '''viewing stones''', is the [[Korea]]n term for small naturally occurring or shaped [[rock (geology)|rocks]] which are traditionally valued.<ref>[http://www.koreanviewingstones.com/ Suseok at KoreanViewingStones.com]; retrieved 2013-2-7.</ref> Such stones are similar to [[Chinese scholar's rocks]] and Japanese [[suiseki]].<ref name="brokaw73">Brokaw, Charles. (2011). [https://books.google.com/books?id=T51TNiU9460C&pg=PA73&dq= ''The Temple Mount Code,'' p. 73].</ref>
''Suseok'' can be any color. There are a wide variety of sizes. ''Suseok'' can weigh hundreds of pounds or less than one pound. The term also means stones which are placed in traditional Korean gardens.
==History== ''Suseok'' began as [[votive art]] over 3000 years ago, and began to be seen as worthy of scholars a thousand years ago. The art usually works on three scales: large installations of monumental shaped stones as ornamental gates; medium-sized shaped stones for landscape decoration within [[Korean gardens]]; and the smaller shaped stones for scholar's tables which is the most important.
Chinese scholar's rocks influenced the development of ''suseok'' in Korea.<ref name="brokaw73"/>
==Evaluation== Early on important sites within landscape were marked with shaped stones, much as those distance markers on post roads. Burial sites were as well given permanent marking by large scale tumulus or mounds, often surrounded by anthropomorphic shaped stones much akin to that of [[Inuit]] or [[First Nations]]' memory markers. The shamanistic belief of nature being alive, and large scaled elements of nature having souls, has led to the continued use of massive sculpted stone in natural forms throughout Korean traditional entranceways as the firstgrowth cedarwood for gates is now rare.
As Confucian scholarship ascended into the golden age of the [[Joseon Dynasty|Joseon]] dynasty, scholar rocks became an essential fixture of the writing tables of the [[yangban]] class of scholars, and a brilliant example of [[Confucian art]]. The repeated Japanese invasions of Korea, culminating with the 50 year occupation period from 1895 to 1945, saw great theft of Korean scholar stones as well as theft of larger pieces taken to Japan from [[Korean gardens]] or [[Seon garden]] and put into the [[Zen garden]] without reference to origins. Recreating a historical approach to Korean scholar stones is difficult, but it is being done.
Smaller ceramic versions of scholar's rocks have been seen cast in celadon, and used as brush-holders, and as well as water droppers for scholar's [[calligraphy]] - particularly in the shape of small mountains.
==Genres of Korean stone art==
* mountain view (horizontal and vertical) * shaped jade mountains * shaped rock crystal mountains * abstract shape * overhanging shapes * organic mineral shapes (calcites, pyrites) * stalactite and stalagmite stelae * shamanistic shape * single stone buddhas * multiple stone buddhas * astrological year figures (dragon, snake, monkey etc.) * tree and house shapes * fossilized fish * fossilized insects * enhanced coloured stones
==Standard reference work==
* Soosuk, #72 in a series of books on Korean culture, Daewonsa Publishing Co, Ltd (Korea, 1989), {{ISBN|89-369-0072-2}} (in Korean)
==See also== * [[Gongshi]] or Chinese scholar's rocks * [[Suiseki]] * [[Korean art]] * [[Korean sculpture]] * [[Korean culture]] * [[List of Korea-related topics]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.bucheon.go.kr/site/homepage/menu/viewMenu?menuid=002003002003 Bucheon Museum of Suseok at Bucheon.go.kr]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Stone art}} [[Category:Korean art]] [[Category:Korean sculpture]] [[Category:Rock art in Asia]]

revision.text:
The '''Symphony No. 2''' of [[Douglas Lilburn]] was completed in 1951, and received its premiere in 1959. It appears to have been revised in 1974.<ref>See: {{OCLC|154285031}}</ref> The work is divided into four movements: *''Prelude: [[Tempo|Moderato]]'' ([[half note]]=betw. 52-56 ([[tempo|tempo in beats per minute]])) *''[[Scherzo]]: [[Tempo#Italian_tempo_markings|Allegro]] [[Tempo#Italian_tempo_markings|vivace]]'' ([[quarter note]]=approx. 152) *''Introduction: Poco lento'' (quarter note=approx. 69) - without pause - *''Finale: Allegro'' ([[half note]]=betw. 116-120)<ref>metronome markings are from the 1979 score.</ref>
A typical performance of the piece lasts around 30 minutes, and several recordings exist. The work was published in 1979 by Price Milburn of [[Wellington]]<ref>See: {{OCLC|8319388}} (e.g. University of Missouri Kansas City, other locations. Typeset miniature score, 116 pages.)</ref> though it seems to have circulated in manuscript copies earlier.<ref>This makes sense as there were several earlier recordings. A holograph of the 1974 revision is at Victoria University of Wellington (see OCLC link), for instance. (According to library and Worldcat, [[holograph]] score- 136 pages.)</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} *Douglas Lilburn. ''The Three Symphonies''. [[New Zealand Symphony Orchestra]], [[James Judd]], rec. 2001 on [[Naxos Records]]
[[Category:Compositions by Douglas Lilburn]] [[Category:20th-century symphonies|Lilburn, Douglas 2]] [[Category:1951 compositions]]
{{symphony-stub}}

'''Symphony No. 3''' by [[Michael Tippett]] is a work for soprano and orchestra with text written by the composer.
It was composed between 1970 and 1972 and received its premiere on 22 June 1972 at the [[Royal Festival Hall]], London, performed by the [[London Symphony Orchestra]] with the soprano [[Heather Harper]] conducted by [[Colin Davis]].
The symphony is notable for its use of [[blues]] and its direct quotation of the opening of the finale of [[Ludwig van Beethoven|Beethoven]]'s [[Symphony No. 9 (Beethoven)|Ninth Symphony]]. The work criticises the ecstatic and utopian understanding of the brotherhood of man as expressed in the ''[[Ode to Joy]]'' and instead stresses man's capacity for both good and evil.<ref>Matthews, p.93</ref> The work is consequently characterised by contrasting and conflicting parts, its overall design being "one massive antithesis".<ref>Kemp, p.438</ref>
==Movements==
The work consists of two parts: # Allegro non troppo e pesante (Arrest) - Allegro molto e con grande energia (Movement) # Allegro molto - Slow Blues (Andante) - Fast blues (Allegro)
==Background==
Tippett's conception of the Third Symphony occurred during a concert in [[Edinburgh]] in 1965 during a performance of either [[Pierre Boulez]]'s [[Piano sonatas (Boulez)|Piano Sonata No. 2]]<ref>Kemp, p.439</ref> or ''[[Pli selon pli]]''.<ref>Bowen, p.117</ref> Tippett detected an absence of harmonic, rhythmic and melodic motion in the work. Such an approach to composition could only be utilised by Tippett if it was presented within the context of a dialectic with its opposite, hence the Third Symphony was constructed on the concepts of "arrest" and "movement" which Tippett likened to the pull and thrust of a jet engine.<ref>Matthews, p.92</ref> Parts 1 and 2 of the work, and their component sections, follow this cycle of "arrest" and "movement".
Describing its creative cycle, Tippett remarked: "The work took seven years of intermittent consideration and eventual creation. From such tiny noting of a future possibility I had to put down a kind of mnemonic shorthand, so that I could remember what I thought the structure of the whole work might be when I’d only experienced the initial moment of conception. ...a great many disjointed, unstructured notions have been noted in my own kind of verbal shorthand. ...the original spontaneous conception of “immobile” polarized against “speedy” (so ridiculously simple, but clearly having the power to initiate the creative process now apparently ready to being) was always the structuring factor. While holding these ideas in my mind over a period of years, allowing them gradually to grow, I come next to a moment when I had nearly everything in my mind except the notes. The symphony so far had a structure and balance; it had ideas about orchestration. Thus I could begin what is usually thought of as the composition. I began at the piano a search for the right sounds. Now I don’t find the precise sounds I want on the piano, but through the piano (this is after all a piece for an orchestra). But I can invent as though the orchestral score were in my head all the time."<ref>Mick Csaky (ed.), ‘Feelings of inner experience’, in How Does it feel? Exploring the world of your senses, (London: Thames and Hudson 1979), 176.</ref>
Tippett wanted to avoid the "[[Dmitri Shostakovich|Shostakovich]] bombast" characteristic of many finales and decided to compose the finale as a set of blues. He possessed a great admiration for [[Bessie Smith]]'s 1925 recording of ''[[St. Louis Blues (song)|St Louis Blues]]'' in particular. Tippett interpreted the repeated bass line of the blues in terms of a [[Henry Purcell|Purcellian]] ground bass, which would make the finale a form of [[passacaglia]]. The most important reason for Tippett's decision to use the blues was its ability to communicate simply and directly.<ref>Kemp, p.439</ref>
By the time Tippett came to compose the symphony in spring 1970, he had already written the text of the four songs for the finale.<ref>Tippett, p.157</ref> [[Gustav Mahler|Mahler]]'s settings of Chinese poems in ''[[Das Lied von der Erde]]'' served as a precedent for Tippett of a work which articulated song text in the shape of a symphony: "I began thus to plan and organize lyrics that would have a shape - of a human being moving from innocence to experience".<ref>Robinson, p.186</ref> The symphony's text was formulated as a critical response to the sentiment embodied in [[Friedrich Schiller|Schiller]]'s ''[[Ode to Joy]]'': Schiller's ecstatic celebration of the brotherhood of man was untenable in a century that had witnessed the [[Holocaust]], [[gulag]]s and the dropping of the atomic bomb on [[Hiroshima]].<ref>Bowen, p.122</ref> In the dramatic fourth song, therefore, Beethoven's Ninth Symphony is quoted three times at climactic points and its message is challenged in the text and music of the work. Tippett's confrontation with Beethoven is suggested from the outset of the piece, the abrupt chords in the first bar being reminiscent of the opening of Beethoven's own [[Symphony No. 3 (Beethoven)|Symphony No. 3]].<ref>Kemp, p.441</ref>
==Manuscript== The Third Symphony is certainly one Tippett’s most peculiar looking manuscripts, and his notational practices deserve closer inspection as they reveal how his conceptual design and the compositional strategies he required to deliver it demanded he entirely re-conceive the orchestra, even his own re-conceptualized post-Priam orchestra found in his Concerto for Orchestra.<ref>Thomas Schuttenhelm, ''The Orchestral Music of Michael Tippett: Creative Development and the Compositional Process'' (London: Cambridge University Press, 2013) 239.</ref>
The manuscript of the work is in the Tippett Collection (Add MS 61796-61798) of the [[British Library]].
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== *{{cite book|last=Bowen|first=Meirion|authorlink=Meirion Bowen|title=Michael Tippett|publisher=Robson|location=London|year=1981}} *{{cite book|last=Kemp|first=Ian|authorlink=Ian Kemp|title=Tippett: The Composer and his Music|publisher=Oxford|location=Oxford|year=1987}} *{{cite book|last=Matthews|first=David|authorlink=David Matthews (composer)|title=Michael Tippett: An Introductory Study|publisher=Faber|location=London|year=1980}} *{{cite book|last=Robinson|first=Suzanne|title=Michael Tippett: Music and Literature|publisher=Ashgate|location=Aldershot|year=2002}} *{{cite book|last=Tippett|first=Michael|authorlink=Michael Tippett|title=Moving Into Aquarius|publisher=Paladin|location=St Albans|year=1974}}
==External links== [http://www.gramophone.net/Issue/Page/January%201975/78/829914/TIPPETT.+Symphony+No.+3.+Heather+Harper+(soprano),+London+Symphony+Orchestra+conducted+by+Colin+Davis.+Philips+6500+662+(2.46).+Notes+and+text+included.+Recorded+in+association+with+the+Rupert+Foundation. ''Gramophone'' 1975 review of the first recording]
{{Michael Tippett}}

revision.comment: Moving from [[Category:Solo piano pieces]] to [[Category:Compositions for solo piano]] using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
The '''Symphony for Solo Piano''' is a large-scale romantic work for piano composed by [[Charles-Valentin Alkan]] and published in 1857. Although it is generally performed as a self-contained work, it comprises studies Nos. 4-7 from the ''Douze [[étude]]s dans tous les tons mineurs (Twelve Studies in all the minor keys)'', Op. 39, each title being prefaced by the word ''Symphonie'' ([[French language|French]]: ''Symphony''). The four movements are titled ''Allegro'', ''[[Funeral march|Marche Funèbre]]'', ''[[Minuet|Menuet]]'', and ''Finale''. Much like the [[Concerto for Solo Piano (Alkan)|Concerto for Solo Piano]], the Symphony is written so as to evoke the broad palette of timbres and harmonic textures available to an orchestra. It is an early example of a [[Piano symphony]]. In the opinion of François Luguenot, it "does not contain the excesses of [Alkan's] Concerto or the Grande Sonate (Op. 33). But, rather like [Alkan's] Sonatine Op. 61, it proves that Alkan was also capable of writing perfectly balanced and almost ‘Classical’ works."Luguenot (2001) Unlike a standard [[classical music|classical]] symphony, each movement is in a different key, rising in [[progressive tonality]] by a [[perfect fourth]].Smith (2000), v.2 p. 117 == Description == === Allegro === [[File:Alkan Symphony for Solo Piano Allegro first theme.png|thumb|upright=1|Opening theme of the Allegro.]][[File:Alkan symphony 2nd movement theme.png|thumb|upright=1|Opening of the Funeral March.]][[File:Alkan symphony movement 4 theme.png|thumb|upright=1|Opening of the Finale.]]The opening movement in C minor is written in [[sonata form]]. The thematic material of the Allegro is almost entirely derived from the opening theme, which appears in octaves in the left hand. === Marche Funèbre === The second movement is in [[ternary form]] with a [[legato]] melody over [[staccato]] chords in the first section and a lyrical [[chorale]] in the middle section. François Luguenot wrote:
The second movement is a [[funeral march]] in F minor, rather [[Gustav Mahler|Mahlerian]] in style. In the original edition the title page read ‘Symphonie: No 2. Marcia funebre sulla morte d’un Uomo da bene ['Funeral march on the death of a good man’], words which have sadly been lost in all subsequent editions. Of course one is reminded of the subtitle of the ‘Marcia funebre’ in Beethoven’s third symphony. But might we not regard this ‘uomo da bene’ as Alkan’s father, Alkan Morhange, who died in 1855, two years before these studies were published?
[[Jack Gibbons]] wrote:[https://lt-lt.facebook.com/JackGibbonsPiano/posts/10151807117194384 Jack Gibbons Facebook entry, 3 July 2013], accessed 3 December 2014 "The funeral march's sense of restraint is borne out by Alkan's marking over the gentle central section, "with contained sorrow" [...] The distant drum roll that interrupts the march near its close adds an Alkanesque sense of disquiet to this already sombre music." === Menuet === The Menuet is in ternary form, like the Marche Funèbre. François Luguenot writes that "the Minuet in B{{music|flat}} minor is in fact a [[scherzo]] that anticipates shades of [[Anton Bruckner|Bruckner]]—full of energy and brightened by a lyrical trio." Adrian Corleonis suggests that "[[Hector Berlioz|Berlioz]] and [[Joseph Haydn|Haydn]] are in closest proximity in the hectic Minuet, combining the spirit of the Ronde du Sabbat and Marche au Supplice from the former's ''[[Symphonie Fantastique]]'', with a palpable debt to the Minuet from the latter's [[String_Quartets,_Op._76_(Haydn)#Opus_76.2C_No._2_.28.22Fifths.22.29|"Les Quintes" Quartet, Op. 76/2]], which Alkan transcribed."Corleonis (1992) === Finale === The final movement is extremely technically demanding. Luguenot comments that "the final Presto in E{{music|flat}} minor, memorably described by [[Raymond Lewenthal]] as a ‘ride in hell’, brings the work to a breathless close." ==Performance history== In the opinion of [[Jack Gibbons]]: "That music of this quality has remained neglected in the 150 or so years since its creation is a shocking scandal ... Alkan performed extracts of the work himself at his series of 'Petits Concerts' in Paris in the 1870s but the next notable performance wasn't until 1938 when [[Egon Petri]] performed the Symphony for [[BBC]] radio in London. Gramophone recordings of the work didn't appear for another 25 years, and though today the work is performed more often than at any time in the past, its appearance in a concert programme is still unusual." == See also == * [[Piano symphony]] * [[Concerto for Solo Piano (Alkan)]] ==References== ;Notes ;Sources * Corleonis, Adrian (1992). "Liner Notes" to Marco Polo CD223285, (recital of Bernard Ringgeisen). * Luguenot, François (2001). "[http://www.hyperion-records.co.uk/al.asp?al=CDA67218 Liner notes]" to Hyperion CDA67128 (recital of [[Marc-André Hamelin]]), accessed 3 December 2014 * Smith, Ronald (2000). ''Alkan: The Man, The Music''. (2 vols. in 1). London: Kahn and Averill. {{ISBN|9781871082739}} {{Alkan études}} {{classical-composition-stub}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Symphony for solo piano}} [[Category:Compositions for solo piano]] [[Category:Études by Charles-Valentin Alkan]] [[Category:Romantic symphonies|Alkan]] [[Category:1857 compositions]]

{{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Syringoma | synonyms = | image = Syringoma.jpg | caption = Syringomas highlighted by white circles | pronounce = | field = | symptoms = | complications = | onset = | duration = | types = | causes = | risks = | diagnosis = | differential = | prevention = | treatment = | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = | deaths = }}
'''Syringomas''' are harmless eccrine [[sweat gland|sweat duct]] [[tumors]], typically found clustered on eyelids, although they may also be found in the [[armpit]]s, abdomen, chest, neck, scalp or groin area including genitals in a symmetric pattern.<ref name="Andrews">{{cite book |author1=James, William D. |author2=Berger, Timothy G. |title=Andrews' Diseases of the Skin: clinical Dermatology |publisher=Saunders Elsevier |location= |year=2006 |pages= |isbn=0-7216-2921-0 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=|display-authors=etal}}</ref>{{Rp|663|date=June 2009}} They are skin-colored or yellowish firm, rounded bumps, 1–3 mm in diameter, and may be confused with [[xanthoma]], [[Milium (dermatology)|milia]], [[hidrocystoma]], [[trichoepithelioma]], and [[xanthelasma]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Skin lesions, tumours and cancers. DermNet NZ|url = http://www.dermnetnz.org/lesions/|website = www.dermnetnz.org|accessdate = 2015-11-15}}</ref> They are more common in women and are most commonly found in middle-aged Asian women. While they can present at any time in life, they typically present during adolescence. They are usually not associated with any other symptoms although can sometimes cause itchiness or irritation.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Syringoma. DermNet NZ|url = http://www.dermnetnz.org/lesions/syringoma.html|website = www.dermnetnz.org|accessdate = 2015-11-15}}</ref>
== Types== * '''Eruptive''' this form typically presents on the anterior chest, abdomen, neck and arms. It presents in successive crops with periods of relief in between times of active rash. * '''Milia-like''' this type of syringoma is typically smaller lesions that have a milky white center that can look like [[Milium (dermatology)|milia]]. * '''Plaque type''' this type is more commonly associated with itchiness and chronic scratching that leads to epidermal thickening similar to [[lichen planus]]. * '''Familial''' some cases of syringoma exhibit a familial pattern in an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance. Chromosome 16q22 has been shown to be involved in the genetic links of syringoma.
=== Associated syndromes ===
Syringomas can be found in association with other symptoms as part of a syndrome. [[Hailey–Hailey disease|Hailey-Hailey]] disease also known as familial benign chronic pemphigus is a blistering disease that can also include syringomas.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Hailey-Hailey disease (benign familial pemphigus). DermNet NZ|url = http://www.dermnetnz.org/systemic/familial-pemphigus.html|website = www.dermnetnz.org|accessdate = 2015-11-15}}</ref>
Several systemic syndromes have also been associated with syringoma including [[diabetes mellitus]], [[down syndrome]], Brooke-Spiegler, and Nicolau-Balus. Specifically, diabetes mellitus is strongly associated with clear cell syringoma consisting of nests of clear cells containing glycogen. It is thought that phosphorylase deficiency, resulting from elevated glucose levels seen in diabetes leads to an accumulation of glycogen in the skin and within the clear cells. The incidence of syringomas has been reported in up to 40 percent of people with Down syndrome and can be associated with a condition [[calcinosis cutis]] which requires prompt medical attention. Brooke-Spiegler syndrome is a rare autosomal dominant syndrome with cutaneous manifestations including syringomas and trichoepitheliomas. Nicolau-Balus is a rare autosomal dominant disorder consisting of atrophoderma vermiculata and syringomas.
== Pathophysiology == [[File:SkinTumors-P8080545.JPG|thumb|Syringoma (eccrine)]] The pathophysiology of syringomas remains largely unknown. Familial patterns presenting in an autosomal dominant pattern suggest a genetic link that can result in varying genetic aberrations in lesions, specifically chromosome 16q22. The most commonly accepted theory is that syringomas are benign growths that arise from the intraepidermal portion of eccrine ducts. Another theory suggests that syringomas are a reactive hyperplasia rather than a true neoplasm resulting after inflammatory processes such as eczema. It has also been suggested that a hamartomatous process could explain eruptive syringomas. A hamartoma of pluripotent stem cells could precede the pathological process. Syringomas may also be under hormonal influence explaining the female predominance.{{citation needed|date=November 2015}}
== Diagnosis == Syringomas can often be diagnosed clinically based on presentation, distribution patterns over the body, lack of associated symptoms and family history. A definitive diagnosis requires a [[skin biopsy]] to allow the tissue to be examined under a microscope. Histologically, syringomas have a characteristic comma ("tadpole") shaped tail of dilated, cystic eccrine ducts.
== Treatment == The goal of treatment is to improve the appearance of lesions since they are otherwise not serious and typically do not cause symptoms. Many treatment methods have been attempted however, complete removal is uncommon. No single treatment method has been shown to consistently work. Both medical and surgical treatments have been studied, each with variable success. Common destructive treatment methods include carbon dioxide lasers, dermabrasion, surgical excision, electrocoagulation and chemical peels. Many of these methods are very time consuming and require multiple treatment sessions.Carbon dioxide lasers are the most commonly practiced method; however, can cause thermal damage leading to scarring in the area. Medical therapies include topical [[atropine]], topical retinoids and oral [[tranilast]].
The most common adverse side effects include redness, skin discoloration and pain. Other side effects include blistering and scarring.
== See also == * [[Acrospiroma]] * [[Hidrocystoma]] * [[List of cutaneous conditions]] * [[List of cutaneous neoplasms associated with systemic syndromes]]
== Notes == {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{italic title}} [[File:Edward-Burne-Jones-Wake-Dearest.jpg|thumb|upright=1.0|''Wake Dearest'', from the printed facsimiles]] '''''The Flower Book''''' by [[Edward Burne-Jones]] (1833–1898) is a series of 38 round watercolours, each about six inches across, painted from 1882 to 1898. The paintings do not depict flowers; rather, they were inspired by the flowers' names. Burne-Jones called them "a series of illustrations to the Names of Flowers". "Not a single flower itself appears", according to his wife Georgiana. They were painted for his private pleasure, many while he was resting at his summer home in [[Rottingdean]], and were described by his wife as the "most soothing piece of work that he ever did".[http://www.leicestergalleries.com/19th-20th-century-paintings/d/the-flower-book%3A-iv-travellers-joy/12075 Leicester Galleries]Wildman (1998), pp. 285–86 In 1905 Georgiana, by then a widow, published a limited edition of high-quality colour [[facsimiles]]. ==Themes and technique== [[File:Edward Burne-Jones Witches Tree (Flower Book).png|thumb|upright=1.0|''Witches' Tree'', from the printed facsimiles]] [[File:Love in a Tangle Burne Jones Brit Museum.jpg|thumb|upright=1.0|''Love in a Tangle'', from the watercolour in the British Museum]] Worked in [[watercolor painting|watercolours]], [[gouache|bodycolour (gouache)]], and gold paint, the paintings reflect the landscape around Rottingdean and include favourite themes from Burne-Jones's work: ''Witches' Tree'' (no. xv) revisits the subject of ''[[The Beguiling of Merlin]]'' and ''Meadow Sweet'' (no. xxxv) features the central figures from ''[[The Last Sleep of Arthur in Avalon]]''. Burne-Jones collected folknames of flowers from many sources, but the greatest number were provided by Eleanor Leighton, Lady Leighton Warren, who shared her "knowledge of the names and legends belonging to flowers".Burne-Jones (1906), p. 118 In a letter to her, he wrote: {{quotation|Pray send me as many names as ever you can, for alack it is not one in ten that I can use. Of course I could make pictures to all, but I want the name and the picture to be one soul together, and indissoluble, as if they could not exist apart; so many lovely names and nothing to be done with them.Burne-Jones (1906), p. 119}} In a later letter, he added, "You see how I want to deal with them: it is not enough to illustrate them—that is such poor work: I want to add to them or wring their secret from them".Burne-Jones (1906), p. 120 ==Publication== On his death, Burne-Jones left the album of flower paintings to his wife [[Georgiana Burne-Jones|Georgiana]], and she published a facsimile edition of 300 copies in 1905 in co-operation with the [[Fine Art Society]] in London. It was printed by Henri Piazza, who hand-stencilled watercolour over [[collotype]]s using the [[Stencil|pochoir]] technique to produce brilliant colours. These copies of the "Book" were sold in both bound and unbound form, with the unbound copies contained in a clamshell box.[http://www.artknowledgenews.com/26_01_2012_03_02_17_the_delaware_art_museum_features_edward_burne_jones_flower_book_illustrations.html Art Knowledge News] The Delaware Art Museum Features Edward Burne-Jones "Flower Book Illustrations" Copies of ''The Flower Book'' are in the collections of the [[Birmingham Museum and Art Gallery|Birmingham Museums and Art Gallery]] and the [[Delaware Art Museum]].[http://www.preraphaelites.org/the-collection/1953P5.5/the-flower-book-rose-of-heaven/ Rose of Heaven], all 38 images can be viewed in a small format by searching the site for "Burne-Jones" and "Flower Book". Retrieved 1 February 2012.[http://www.delart.org/exhibitions/flowerbook.html Delaware Art Museum] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120214083032/http://www.delart.org/exhibitions/flowerbook.html |date=14 February 2012 }} A Secret Book of Designs: The Burne-Jones Flower Book. Retrieved 1 February 2012. The art publisher [[Taschen]] reprinted the book in 1994 in a modern format without using the pochoir technique. The [[British Museum]] bought the original album of paintings from Georgiana Burne-Jones in 1909.Gere (1994), p. 98[https://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/pd/e/edward_burne-jones,_love_in_a.aspx Edward Burne-Jones, Love in a tangle, a watercolour], British Museum. Retrieved 1 February 2012. ===Prints=== ''for the complete set of prints see'' [[Commons:The Flower Book by Edward Burne-Jones]] File:The Flower Book - Love in a Mist.jpg|No. i
'''''Love in a Mist'''''
''[[Nigella damascena]]'' File:The Flower Book - Golden Thread.jpg|No. ii
'''''Golden Thread'''''
''[[Coptis trifolia|Coptis trifolia groenlandica]]'' File:The Flower Book - Jacob's Ladder 1905.jpg|No. iii
'''''Jacob's Ladder'''''
''[[Polemonium caeruleum]]'' File:The Flower Book - Traveller's Joy.jpg|No. iv
'''''Traveller's Joy'''''
''[[Clematis vitalba]]'' ==Notes== [[File:Georgiana_Burne-Jones_by_Edward_Coley_Burne-Jones.jpg|right|thumb|''Portrait of Georgiana Burne-Jones'' by Edward Burne-Jones, 1883, showing her holding a different book of flowers.]] {{reflist}} ==References== * {{cite book|last=Burne-Jones|first=Georgiana|title=Memorials of Edward Burne-Jones|volume = 1|year=1906|publisher=Macmillan|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jMVLAQAAIAAJ|accessdate=1 February 2012}} * {{cite book | last = Gere | first = J. A. | title = Pre-Raphaelite drawings in the British Museum | publisher = British Museum Press | location = London | year = 1994 | isbn = 0-7141-2603-9 }} * {{cite book|last= Wildman|first=Stephen|title=Edward Burne-Jones, Victorian artist-dreamer | url =http://libmma.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/ref/collection/p15324coll10/id/67586 | publisher=Metropolitan Museum of Art|year=1998|isbn= 0-87099-859-5}} ==External links== {{Commons category|The Flower Book by Edward Burne-Jones}} *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zozvLknxHZg ''The Flower Book Edward Burne Jones''], YouTube video, 3:05, showing all 38 watercolours. {{Edward Burne-Jones}} {{Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Flower Book}} [[Category:Watercolor paintings]] [[Category:Paintings by Edward Burne-Jones]] [[Category:Painting series]] [[Category:Angels in art]] [[Category:Witches in art]]

{{Infobox film | name = The Oath | image = The Oath poster.jpg | border = no | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Ike Barinholtz]] | producer = {{Plainlist| * Ike Barinholtz * Raymond Mansfield * [[Sean McKittrick]] * Andrew C. Robinson * David Stassen }} | writer = Ike Barinholtz | starring = {{Plainlist|<!--PER BILLING--> * Ike Barinholtz * [[Tiffany Haddish]] * [[Nora Dunn]] * [[Chris Ellis (actor)|Chris Ellis]] * Jon Barinholtz * [[Meredith Hagner]] * [[Carrie Brownstein]] * [[Billy Magnussen]] * [[John Cho]]<!--PER BILLING--> }} | music = [[Bret Mazur]] | cinematography = Cary Lalonde | editing = Jack Price | production companies = {{Plainlist| * QC Entertainment * 23/34 Pictures * Aperture Media Productions }} | distributor = {{Plainlist| * [[Roadside Attractions]] * Topic Studios }} | released = {{film date|2018|9|25|[[Los Angeles Film Festival|LAFF]]|2018|10|12|United States}} | runtime = 93 minutes<ref>{{cite web|url=https://tickets.lafilmfestival.com/Online/default.asp?doWork::WScontent::loadArticle=Load&BOparam::WScontent::loadArticle::article_id=78E0839D-2A63-49AB-9E38-2CD7F6F8164C&BOparam::WScontent::loadArticle::context_id=F3C10D14-6FCD-4CD8-8A6D-7BC2BF500FE7|title=The Oath|website=[[Los Angeles Film Festival]]|accessdate=August 22, 2018}}</ref> | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = $401,463<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=theoath2018.htm|title=The Oath (2018)|website=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=November 3, 2018}}</ref> }}
'''''The Oath''''' is a 2018 American [[black comedy]] film written and directed by [[Ike Barinholtz]], in his directorial debut. In addition to Barinholtz, the film stars [[Tiffany Haddish]], [[John Cho]], [[Carrie Brownstein]], [[Billy Magnussen]], [[Meredith Hagner]], Jon Barinholtz, [[Nora Dunn]] and [[Chris Ellis (actor)|Chris Ellis]], and follows a politically divided family at Thanksgiving after the U.S. government requires all citizens to sign a loyalty pledge.
It had its world premiere at the [[Los Angeles Film Festival]] on September 25, 2018, and was released in the United States on October 12, 2018, by [[Roadside Attractions]]. The film received mixed reviews from critics, although Haddish's performance was praised.
==Premise== In a dystopian future, people across America are required to sign a controversial political document, “The Patriot’s Oath” (to the U.S. president), by [[Black Friday (shopping)|Black Friday]], the day after [[Thanksgiving]]. Meanwhile, a young couple hosts a Thanksgiving dinner in which political discussion about the Oath among their family members erupts into violence and mayhem.
==Cast== * [[Ike Barinholtz]] as Chris, Kai’s husband * [[Tiffany Haddish]] as Kai, Chris’s wife * [[John Cho]] as Agent Peter * [[Carrie Brownstein]] as Alice * [[Billy Magnussen]] as Agent Mason * [[Meredith Hagner]] as Abbie * Jon Barinholtz as Pat * [[Nora Dunn]] as Eleanor * [[Chris Ellis (actor)|Chris Ellis]] as Hank * [[Matt Corboy]] as Clint Marks * [[Jay Duplass]] * Priah Ferguson as Hardy * Henry Kaufman as Asher * [[Max Greenfield]]
==Production== In September 2017, it was announced [[Ike Barinholtz]] would write, direct, and star in the film. Barinholtz will produce the film alongside [[Sean McKittrick]], Ray Mansfield, Edward H. Hamm, Jr., Andrew Robinson, and David Stassen, under their QC Entertainment and 24/34 Pictures banners, respectively.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/ike-barinholtz-oath-satirical-thriller-1202574937/|title=Ike Barinholtz to Write, Direct, Star in Satirical Thriller ‘The Oath’|website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|first=Dave|last=McNary|date=September 27, 2017|accessdate=June 13, 2018}}</ref> In December 2017, [[Tiffany Haddish]], [[John Cho]], [[Carrie Brownstein]], [[Billy Magnussen]], [[Meredith Hagner]], Jon Barinholtz, [[Nora Dunn]] and [[Chris Ellis (actor)|Chris Ellis]] joined the cast of the film. Haddish will also serve as an executive producer.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/tiffany-haddish-john-cho-join-ike-barinholtz-satirical-thriller-oath-1067308|title=Tiffany Haddish, John Cho Join Ike Barinholtz in Satirical Thriller 'The Oath' (Exclusive)|website=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|first=Borys|last=Kit|date=December 13, 2017|accessdate=June 13, 2018}}</ref>
===Filming=== [[Principal photography]] began in December 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/tiffany-haddish-ike-barinholtz-oath-1202639952/|title=Tiffany Haddish Joins Ike Barinholtz in Satirical Thriller ‘The Oath’|website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|first=Dave|last=McNary|date=December 13, 2017|accessdate=June 13, 2018}}</ref>
==Release== In June 2018, [[Roadside Attractions]] and Topic Studios acquired distribution rights to the film.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://deadline.com/2018/06/ike-barinholtz-the-oath-tiffany-haddish-release-date-roadside-attractions-topic-studios-1202410060/|title=Ike Barinholtz’s Dark Comedy ‘The Oath’ Lands At Roadside & Topic Studios|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|first=Patrick|last=Hipes|date=June 13, 2018|accessdate=June 13, 2018}}</ref> It had its world premiere at the [[Los Angeles Film Festival]] on September 25, 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://deadline.com/2018/08/the-oath-los-angeles-film-festival-world-premiere-ike-barinholtz-tiffany-haddish-1202450800/|title=Ike Barinholtz & Tiffany Haddish’s ‘The Oath’ To World Premiere At Los Angeles Film Festival|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|first=Patrick|last=Hipes|date=August 22, 2018|accessdate=August 22, 2018}}</ref> The film was released on October 12, 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/schedule/?view=changes&p=.htm|title=The Oath|website=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=July 10, 2018}}</ref>
==Reception== On [[review aggregator]] [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film holds an approval rating of 60% based on 78 reviews, with an average rating of 6/10. The website's critical consensus reads, "''The Oath'' draws on hyper-partisan modern politics for a pointedly funny satire that hits its targets hard and often enough to more than achieve its desired discomfort."<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/the_oath_2018|title=The Oath (2018)|work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|publisher=[[Fandango Media]]|accessdate=October 30, 2018}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], the film has a weighted average score of 58 out of 100, based on 27 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews".<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.metacritic.com/movie/the-oath-2018|title=The Oath reviews|website=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=October 27, 2018}}</ref>
Michael O'Sullivan of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' called the film's screenplay "clever and sharp" and wrote it anchors itself as "at times all-too-true-to-life."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/goingoutguide/movies/the-oath-is-a-political-satire-thats-ripped-like-a-band-aid-from-todays-headlines/2018/10/09/c9c2a09c-c739-11e8-9b1c-a90f1daae309_story.html|title=Review {{!}} ‘The Oath’ is a political satire that’s ripped, like a Band-Aid, from today’s headlines|website=Washington Post|language=en|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
